They will probably want to do an ultrasound also, since it can tell if it's a cyst (harmless). If you are young and have dense breast tissue, an MRI might clarify the issue. Remember, most biopsies are benign. You should ask your doctor what the next steps will be. It really helps to have someone go with you to your appointment to be a second set of ears. In the meantime stay busy doing things you enjoy and do not google your symptoms. This site has reliable info, but you have no way of knowing about the info on google. (((HUGS)))

Posts.Content: Apr 22, 2012 11:34AM - edited Apr 22, 2012 11:35AM by Wren44 Sorry you have to be here, but a wonderful site for lots of support. It will be OK. I had a lumpectomy originally with radiation to follow. The margins weren't wide enough, so my surgeon returned for better margins. Darned if that didn't turn up a whole new tumor that didn't show on the Mammo. So I elected to get a mastectomy. I took it easy a little longer with the MX, but didn't need pain meds after the first couple of days. The margins on my MX were good, so no radiation needed. I chose not to get reconstruction because I'm 71 and didn't want more surgery. I wear a lightweight silicone form and look completely normal in my clothing. If I were in my 30's or 40's, my decision might have been different on reconstruction. So remember to breathe. It's really scary in the beginning because your mind can conjure up images that are worse than reality. This is a good site for facts without sensation.

Posts.Content: Feb 3, 2013 10:32PM Wren44 wrote: A diagnosis of BC requires a biopsy with tissue read by a pathologist. There are people surprised by results all the time. When I saw the mammo pictures, my tumor had a very characteristic shape that indicates cancer. My nurse told me just before the biopsy that they were expecting to find cancer. I was glad she gave me a heads up because I was clueless. So, there's nothing definite until the biopsy results are back, but the picture sounds pretty suspicious. There are a couple of things that look like BC on a mammogram and are benign. I hope you're able to get the biopsy right away, because this waiting is the toughest part. And stay off Dr. Google, please. This site has accurate and up to date info. On Google, you don't know how old the info is and whether it is still considered accurate. Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2014 05:32PM Wren44 wrote: Welcome Idunno. It's usually difficult for caregivers to look for and accept support. As you said, you're used to being the support for others. My niece lost her husband a little over a year ago and she attended a group for widowed men and women. She said it was extremely helpful for her. Do get the mammogram and don't freak out if they want additional tests. Lots of time they send you for an ultrasound because it can tell if it's a cyst filled with fluid. Lots of women are sent for a biopsy, because that's the best way to tell for sure what's going on. And the majority of women who have biopsies are found to not have cancer. So there's plenty of reasons to not worry. My attitude is to not worry until I get there and know there's something to worry about. Please let us know what you find out. And never hesitate to come here to get support or vent or whatever you need at the time. (((((HUGS)))))

Posts.Content: Jan 30, 2017 01:51PM Wren44 wrote: At this point, ask for copies of everything and keep them together in one place. There were a lot of things in the reports that I didn't understand at the time and went back to when I'd learned more. You're entitled to copies of your medical records and most docs are willing to give them to you. Just say you want to be able to read them when your mind isn't whirling. I ended up with a mastectomy (my choice) and had 5 and 8yo grandsons. I try to keep covered around them, but decided how I would explain it if they noticed. I was going to tell them it's like finding a bad spot in an apple. You cut it out and the rest of the apple is ok. Sometimes you find another bad spot and in the end you decide it's not worth keeping. They haven't noticed or asked, but I felt better having an explanation prepared. Don't worry about thinking you "caused" it by doing anything. The biggest risk factor is being female. Women on here have led all kinds of lives. Some exercised and ate organic and others were couch potatoes who ate what they wanted. Both kinds ended up with cancer. Stick to a healthy diet and moderate exercise which will do you good in the future anyway.
Posts.Title: I'm joining the club and so scared right now bratmobile singlemom1

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2017 11:25PM Wren44 wrote: Genji, There are ways to do brief radiation. I would ask your doctor if one of those could be done. The normal course is several weeks with a dose done each day. The first appointment is a long one while they get everything set up, then it just takes a few minutes. You would have to go in every day. If you have the mastectomy, you might still need radiation if the margins are bad, but probably not. I had a lumpectomy with poor margins and had to go back. A second, hidden, tumor was found when I went back. At that point, I decided on mastectomy. The mastectomy was a bit longer recovery, but not difficult. As someone mentioned, the lymph node sample was more painful. I didn't need radiation after the mastectomy. I was 71 when diagnosed and 76 now. I have been happy with my choice. Good luck on your decision and treatment. Please let us know how you're doing.

Do take someone with you. My surgeon was OK with my taping the interview. I only told a few people about my diagnosis. They were awesome support. These were people I was really close to. I didn't need chemo, so there was nothing for other people to notice. And I missed all the stupid comments that people make. Once you've seen the surgeon and oncologist, you'll have a much clearer picture of your choices. Then it will be easier to make decisions. My mastectomy was only one side, so I was OK sleeping in bed with pillows and could raise my other arm as high as needed, so no real life changes there. Let us know what your doctors advise. Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2012 12:28PM Wren44 wrote: rlwh, I'm glad you found this site now rather than after diagnosis like me. There is a world of support here from people who do 'get it'. They are superb hand holders. I'm a retired mental health case manager. If you handled the stress of that job, you'll be fine. In addition to stress reduction techniques, exercise will help burn off the stress hormones. Just before surgery, my BP was thru the roof. I managed to bring it down 20 pts by breathing exercises. Still high, but not dangerously so. Start now getting copies of all your results and keeping them together in a file or notebook. And take someone else with you to appointments. It's hard to remember everything that is said. Four ears are better than two. Sending good wishes. Please keep us informed.
Posts.Title: Awaiting biopsy to diagnose cancer; worried and sad rlwh rlwh

Posts.Content: Aug 30, 2014 01:30AM Wren44 wrote: It does seem totally overwhelming in the beginning. Take a deep breath. Things will work out. If you have a lumpectomy, you won't miss a lot of work time. You may have to take some time off at the end of radiation because your job is physical, but some women are able to work right through. Talking to a social worker connected to your hospital about financial issues might be very helpful. You'll feel better once your plans are in order and you know what will happen. You can ask your doctor for something to deal with the anxiety right now, but be sure it won't interfere with your work. It's really helpful to concentrate only on the next step as things unfold. Sometimes a good cry in private is what you need. Please keep posting here - we get it. Hugs.

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2013 12:41AM Wren44 wrote: Ducky, Flying is way less harrowing than being with some drivers. Mostly it's just boring. Once you take off you get above the clouds, and that's all you can see. Be sure to take a book or magazine to read and something to eat. I always take almonds and dried apricots and sometimes cookies. Any more, all you get on the plane is a snack and a pretty pitiful one at that. When you get to the gate, tell the gate person that you need pre-boarding. They let folks who might be slow or have kids in hand go first. If walking is difficult or slow, you can ask for meet and assist. They will have a wheelchair or a little vehicle that holds about 6 people and take you to the gate. I worked for Pan Am in Houston for several years and we flew everywhere. After I quit, we took a car trip to western Texas. The kids wanted to know what time zone we were in and we were still inside the city limits!

I read a paper saying that hormonals work to prevent recurrence, but did not increase longevity.

Posts.Content: Feb 27, 2013 12:21AM Wren44 wrote: English teacher, It's pretty common to have to go back for better margins after a lumpectomy. If it's .5mm from the surgical edge, it's too close for comfort. They prefer 2-3mm margins. In my case, they found an entirely new tumor when they went back for better margins, so I decided on a mastectomy. It sound like you have caught it early and it's not aggressive, which is great. In the diagnosis part of this website there's a part on reading your path report, which may explain more.

Posts.Content: Feb 16, 2013 12:43AM Wren44 wrote: Take a deep breath and slowly exhale. Of course you're scared. You'll feel better once you've seen the surgeon and have a plan. It's pretty common for mammos and MRIs to show different sizes. Often the size changes after surgery. My MRI showed an area next to the tumor that was suspicious but turned out to be normal changes. I was diagnosed at 71 and take a lot of meds. So far the BC has only added one. I honestly think you'll do fine. Stay off Google for cancer info. There's no way of telling if it's accurate or outdated. This site has reliable information. You might try "cancer center ratings" and see if there's a website that has information on various ones. There may be people on here who have first hand knowledge of the one you're planning to go to. If you don't get answers, try a new post asking about cancer treatment in your state or part of the country. This weekend try to distract yourself with activities you enjoy. Exercise helps anxiety. And Monday you'll get a clearer picture. (((((HUGS)))))

Posts.Content: May 7, 2013 12:26AM Wren44 wrote: Tracyinva, We can all relate to the feeling of shock and crying. It's a good idea to take someone else with you to the appointments, so there's another set of ears. There's a lot of good information on this site about choices and options. Usually lumpectomy is followed by radiation. Mastectomy (removal of the whole breast) might not need radiation if there was nothing close to the chest. I was told that the outcomes are the same as far as recurrence is concerned. If you are considering reconstruction, you should talk to a plastic surgeon about options for that. There are several ways to reconstruct depending on circumstances. A plastic surgeon could recommend the ones you might use.  Although you're in shock right now, you have time to research and make choices. Everyone wants it out NOW, but most tumors grow pretty slowly. Your appointment on Wed will probably be spent talking about your choices and what the doctors recommend. There's a list of questions on this site that you can print and take with you to your appointment. They may have enough info from the biopsy to know the hormone markers and grade (how quickly it is growing). Those things might influence your choice. In the meantime, read some of the info here and stay OFF Dr. Google. You know the info here is accurate. Please come back and let us know how it goes. ((((((HUGS))))))
